title: Alzheimer's prevention
content: Peter is joined by writer, director, actress, and founder of HFC, Lauren Miller Rogen, and previous podcast guest and director of the Alzheimer’s Prevention Clinic at Weill Cornell Medicine and New York-Presbyterian, Dr. Richard Isaacson. In this episode, Lauren tells the heartbreaking story of watching members of her family succumb to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) which motivated her to proactively address her own risk with Richard’s guidance. Richard discusses the various genetic and lifestyle factors that influence the risk of AD and uses Lauren’s unique situation to explain how he diagnoses patients and personalizes care. They go through Lauren’s protocol of preventative measures that have already produced marked results, and end with the uplifting message that one’s genetic predisposition does not seal one’s fate.

title: Q&A on Alzheimer’s disease drug therapy
content: Peter interviews Dr. Richard Isaacson, director of the Alzheimer’s Prevention Clinic at Weill Cornell Medicine and New York-Presbyterian, about the latest developments in Alzheimer’s disease drug therapy. They discuss the recent FDA approval of aducanumab, the first drug to target the underlying pathology of Alzheimer’s disease, and the controversy surrounding its approval. They also cover other drugs in development, the importance of early detection and intervention, and lifestyle factors that can reduce the risk of Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Alzheimer's disease and its risk factors
content: We discuss Lauren’s deep family history of Alzheimer’s disease (3:10); The influence of genetics, epigenetics, and lifestyle on Alzheimer’s disease risk (13:45); The various manifestations of Alzheimer’s disease depending on the location of pathology (29:30); The three stages of Alzheimer’s disease (34:45); Richard’s deep exploration into Lauren’s family history revealing clues about a diagnosis and a roadmap to successful disease mitigation (39:15); How exercise reduces Alzheimer’s disease risk, and the different risk between males and females (58:00); Why knowing your APOE status is important, and whether certain people should be wearier of head trauma (1:08:00); Unique treatment for people with the ApoE4 variant (1:36:30); Cognitive testing procedures, and how Lauren’s tests furthered her commitment to her disease prevention protocol (1:41:45); The relevance of sense of smell and hearing in Alzheimer’s disease risk and prevention (1:50:00);

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Factors Contributing to Chronic Illness
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides insight into the factors that contribute to chronic illness.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, Depression, and More
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Robert Sapolsky discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia, as well as the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

content: Robert Sapolsky talks about the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Family history of Alzheimer’s disease
content: Her maternal grandfather had Alzheimer’s disease (AD), started showing symptoms in his late fifties/early sixties and was put into a nursing home when Lauren was 9 or 10. After Lauren’s grandfather passed away, her grandmother began showing symptoms of AD and she also ended up in a nursing home and died in her mid 70s.

title: Losing her mother to Alzheimer’s disease
content: At the time of Lauren’s college graduation, she noticed her mother (just 52 years old) repeating stories—something that really worried Lauren. Within a year or two, she was losing her ability carry out her job as a teacher and function as a cognitively healthy person would. At this point, they brought her to a doctor and Lauren’s mother was given “as much as a diagnosis as one could get at that time”. At this point, it was clear there was something going on in the family with AD. Lauren was confronted with a difficult mix of emotions, including fear, anger, depression, and denial (Lauren said her father was in the most denial). In 2005, Lauren finally admitted out loud that her mom was suffering from AD. What scared her mother the most about having AD: “And she told me that she wasn’t scared for her. She was scared for me and my brother and my dad, because I think she got that at some point she may not know what’s happening, and that the weight would be on us.”

title: Devastating consequences
content: At this point, Lauren was a young adult and just beginning to interact with her mother as a friend more so than a mom. Being deprived of the opportunity to develop this friendship with her mother was very difficult for Lauren. Lauren was intent on finding a way to help her mother, but despite her best efforts, she found nothing. “There was nothing. And so it was a really scary, hard time where I felt like I could do nothing and that this train had left the station for my mom and that was it.” —Lauren Miller Rogen

title: Richard’s perspective on Alzheimer’s disease
content: Richard sees it as an insidious disease – he “hates” it because it not only robs the person with it of who they are, but also robs the entire family. Alzheimer’s begins in the brain about a decade before the first symptoms of memory loss, and this is something many doctors are still unaware of. Onset of Alzheimer’s symptoms usually occurs in one’s seventies, but with early-onset Alzheimer’s disease, symptoms can begin in one’s forties or fifties.

title: Genetic risk factors for early-onset Alzheimer’s disease
content:
While genetics is often responsible for an early onset of Alzheimer’s disease, Richard points out that there are cases when there is more to the story that can cause an earlier onset (lifestyle, head trauma, comorbidities, etc.)
Genes known to cause early-onset Alzheimer’s disease: Variations in the genes for presenilin-1, presenilin-2, and amyloid precursor protein gene mutation
These variations are quite rare (far less than 1% of people): 
Richard has only had a few patients (out of more than 1,500) that have had one of these variations
Peter has never had a patient with one of them

title: Genetic and epigenetic causes pushing onset of AD earlier in life
content:
Most people that get AD earlier in life don’t have “early-onset Alzheimer’s disease” but rather they have a “milieu of things” aka polygenic risk and epigenetics that simply push the onset of AD earlier in life
For example, the apolipoprotein E (ApoE) gene variants
The E4 variant raises AD risk
In contrast, the E2 variant is protective and the E3 variant, which is most common, is neutral

title: Lifestyle and behavioral characteristics
content:
Diet
Exercise
Head trauma
Comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, high blood pressure, cholesterol)

title: Stress on the family
content: The stress for the family caring for a family member with AD cannot be understanded. Lauren’s father was taking the brunt of the stress as the primary caretaker. On the plane back home from Lauren’s wedding, her mother was acting out and screaming and had an accident on the seat — her father described is as “the worst five hours of his life”.

title: How the location of pathology influences disease outcome
content: The progression of Alzheimer’s is commonly represented by Braak staging, which describes how different changes in function and behavior occur as Alzheimer’s pathology spreads throughout the brain. Although understanding of Alzheimer’s symptoms was once limited to just changes in short-term memory, it is now known that symptoms are much more diverse and related to which areas of the brain are affected by the pathology. Differences in manifestation are mainly dictated by which regions of the brain are affected by the disease. For example, when someone has pathology in the back of the brain, where vision processing occurs, they may have difficulty interpreting images. Based on this, Peter offers the analogy that like cancer, Alzheimer’s is more than just one disease.

title: How would Richard think about Lauren’s mom’s case based on what Lauren described?
content: Her symptoms began with little repeating of stories, and memory glitches around 52 to 54 resulting in a modified work schedule. Six years later, she’s having trouble caring for herself, maybe not recognizing her daughter, and then having emotional behavioral psychiatric components. That sounds like Alzheimer’s disease—progressive short-term memory loss, plus behavioral changes, plus other things. She started in the mild cognitive impairment phase with the symptoms (stage 2 of AD).

title: Richard’s deep exploration into Lauren’s family history revealing clues about a diagnosis and a roadmap to successful disease mitigation
content: Lauren’s mother’s brother, who was 5 years older than her mother, started showing symptoms in his mid-60s. Knowing how destructive the disease was for her mother (who was already bedridden at this point),  Lauren sought out the best east coast physician and was recommended into Richard. Shortly after connecting her uncle with Richard, Lauren wanted to visit the clinic and meet Richard. During her visit, she ended up demanding to become a patient. As Richard recounts, Lauren shot her arm out and said “Take my blood now. Let’s do it.”

title: Exploring family history — the “detective work” (Step 1)
content: Richard was able to see signs of decline in both of Lauren’s grandparents based on changes in their handwriting and their choice of words in Lauren’s mother’s and uncle’s high-school yearbooks, which were five years apart. Based on seeing video of Lauren’s mother earlier in her progression, Richard sensed something more than just Alzhiemer’s was going on – perhaps dementia with Lewy bodies, as seen in Parkinson’s disease and consistent with the observed handwriting changes in the yearbooks. Word choice can also be telling — he mentions a study in nuns whose risk of dementia was predicted by autobiographies they wrote in their late teens, 60 years earlier. Coincidentally, Lauren’s great uncle was a patient of Richard’s brother (which helped with understanding family history).

title: Risk factors for Alzheimer's disease
content: At this point in the process, the main question Richard had was: Despite both having two copies of the ApoE4 variant, Lauren’s mom had AD symptoms much sooner than her uncle. Why? Risk of the ApoE4 variant is more pronounced in women, possibly related to menopause. Lauren’s mother had a hysterectomy, which may have been a contributing factor due to the loss of estrogen. Lifestyle factors: She never exercised (uncle was an avid exerciser). She ate a lot of sugar. Bad sleep habits (same with her uncle).

title: How exercise reduces Alzheimer’s disease risk, and the different risk between males and females
content: Richard considers high-intensity interval training to be the most important factor in Alzheimer’s prevention. Lauren reiterates that there was a big difference in physical activity between her mother and the rest of the family – Lauren, her brother, and her uncle were all athletes while her mother was more intellectual and preferred reading. Richard was first inspired to better understand the greater Alzheimer’s risk among women after prodding from Maria Shriver. What Richard believes to be happening in women: Perimenopause is a “brain disease”. During perimenopause there are metabolic shifts in the brain that can predispose to acceleration of Alzheimer’s pathology. He also believes that this is underappreciated and can be countered with appropriate use of estrogen replacement. The disruption of sleep, the brain fog, problems with processing speed and attention, are all symptoms of perimenopause. Perimenopause transition is a huge unrealized risk factor for progression to dementia in an Alzheimer’s susceptible woman.

title: Factors contributing to risk in women
content: Lauren’s mother’s hysterectomy was likely a contributing factor in her progression. Other factors contributing to risk in women: Widowhood:“widowhood is a astronomically important risk factor for cognitive decline and dementia” Abdominal obesity: women with an enlarged waist circumference have a 39% increase in dementia risk Interestingly, in men, muscle mass is a more important predictor than body fat, but we do not yet know why

title: Why knowing your APOE status is important, and whether certain people should be wearier of head trauma
content: Lauren has one copy of ApoE4 and prefers knowing – she feels empowered knowing that she is doing what she can to offset the risk. Her test revealed that she has E3/E4 (which is less risky that E4/E4). Peter has been criticized by at least one primary care physician for informing people of their ApoE status. But the criticism comes from the thinking that there’s nothing you can do to change your course (which isn’t true). A quick example, people with E4/E4 don’t absorb omega-3 fats from eating fatty fish very well, therefore they should be supplementing with omega-3 from an early age to protect the brain. The REVEAL study showed that disclosing ApoE4 status did not cause clinically significant anxiety or depression. Head trauma may be more of a concern in individuals with the ApoE4 variant, which is additional justification for testing. Peter believes knowing the child’s ApoE status would be an important factor in choosing to play contact sports like football. Richard agrees that playing sports like football can impose increased risk in conjunction with being an ApoE4 carrier, but also acknowledges that it is a difficult topic – “These are really difficult conversations to have, but knowledge is power”

title: How Richard uses genetic testing to personalize care
content: There are about 30 genes that are known to influence Alzheimer’s risk and Richard thinks are important. This is a complicated topic because risk is influenced by the combination of gene variants. For example, Richard considers TOMM40 to be an important gene, and its influence can vary depending on ApoE4 status. Other genes Richard looks at: Vascular genes like FTO and other genes related to lipid metabolism like PCSK9. He also pays attention to longevity genes such as those related to FOXOs and Klotho. The gene for TNF-α, an inflammatory cytokine, is another factor that can modulate the risk associated with the ApoE4 variant. Lauren has a variant of the gene for TNF-α that increases her risk, and Richard and Peter have adjusted her protocol accordingly

title: TNF-α variant and cocoa flavanols and curcumin for lowering inflammation
content: Laren’s mother also had this TNF-α variant, but her uncle did not. Lowering inflammation: Because of her TNF-α variant, she is on a purified form of cocoa flavanols and a nanoparticle version of curcumin (Theracurmin). A study has shown Theracurmin to improve cognitive function and decrease amyloid accumulation in healthy adults.

title: ApoE4 gene and Omega-3, Vitamin D, and B-vitamin complex for lowering Alzheimer's risk
content: Defining a high risk patient: If their family history is notable. They have at least one copy of the ApoE4 gene. Lauren’s protocol: Exercise: Because of Lauren’s ApoE4 status, exercise – particularly high-intensity interval training – is emphasized in her protocol. Omega-3 fats (EPA and DHA): Her E4 status make this more important—A study involving 2 g of DHA supplementation showed that less of it gets to the cerebral spinal fluid of people with the ApoE4 variant. Lowering homocysteine: Lauren takes a B-vitamin complex (which has B12, B6, and folic acid, etc.) to address her homocysteine levels. Optimizing Vitamin D: Supplementation was also emphasized in Lauren’s protocol because her blood concentration was low (less than 20 ng/mL).

title: Magnesium L-threonate for improving cognitive function
content: What about magnesium supplementation? Peter is a big fan of magnesium L-threonate (Magtein) because the L-threonate helps the magnesium enter the brain more easily. A small study has shown magnesium L-threonate to improve cognitive function in people with mild to moderate dementia. Richard has traditionally favored magnesium glycinate based on its use for headaches and it being well tolerated, but he is intrigued by magnesium L-threonate. Richard also believes that magnesium L-threonate may help with sleep, which he has found helpful for “stressed out type A people”.

title: How ApoE4 influences risk and prevention
content: Richard’s team published a review in 2018 specifically describing the role of ApoE4 in guiding clinical prevention. Being an ApoE4 carrier exacerbates the negative effects of being sedentary. Tobacco use has more of a negative effect in ApoE4 carriers. Although the data is confusing, ApoE4 carriers should maybe be more conservative with alcohol consumption, with there potentially being benefit from completely abstaining. Cognitive engagement may be more important for ApoE4 carriers, but the data is unclear here as well. As already mentioned, ApoE4 carriers need higher doses of omega-3 fatty acids. A trial is underway to determine the influence of saturated fat and a high-glycemic diet on ApoE4 carriers.

title: Richard’s mixed opinion on CBD and THC as a tool for disease prevention
content: Richard is open minded to CBD and THC, but considers this a difficult topic. He thinks the benefit is dependent on the ratio of CBD to THC. He also thinks consuming it in edible form makes more sense than smoking it. Evidence in regard to helping versus accelerating Alzheimer’s pathology is mixed. Based on this Richard is “not anti-CBD,” but is “not pro” THC (he says he’s “in the middle”). Richard thinks the answer to CBD and THC is one rooted in precision medicine – it depends on the patient, and the situation should be objectively measured by tracking things like sleep and cognitive function.

title: Cognitive testing procedures, and how Lauren’s tests furthered her commitment to her disease prevention protocol
content: Richard uses a modified form of the Alzheimer’s prevention cognitive composite (validated in this study), which is largely based on the NIH Toolbox of cognitive assessments. The testing he uses is sensitive enough to detect changes in brain function before symptoms occur. Testing is not perfect because people have good days and bad days. As Lauren put it, she only “half started” in the beginning, exercising and slightly improving her diet, but not doing everything she needed to. On one of Lauren’s visits to Richard’s clinic following a stressful period in her life, she did poorly on the cognitive testing, indicating that her lifestyle at that point was pushing her in the wrong direction. After Richard expressed serious concern, Lauren committed to putting in more effort, and it was at about this point that she also started working with Peter. Results so far for Lauren: When Lauren first saw Richard, her cognitive performance was below average, but now it is more than a standard deviation above average. Despite possible confounders, Richard says unequivocally her brain is functioning better than it was before she really took her Alzheimer’s disease prevention protocol seriously.

title: The relevance of sense of smell and hearing in Alzheimer’s disease risk and prevention
content: Loss of smell and inability to identify certain smells were originally viewed as warning signs for Parkinson’s disease, but as Richard puts it, this can and also be “a harbinger of Alzheimer’s disease”. Hearing loss is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease. In the 2020 report of the Lancet Commission, hearing loss was identified as one of the strongest modifiable risk factors for dementia. Richard feels that screening for hearing, perhaps at a certain age, should be included in medical evaluations.

title: The emotional benefit of knowing you have control over your mental and physical health
content: Lauren feels like there’s no reason to believe you’re going to get Alzheimer’s disease, no matter your genetics. She says that the fear has dissipated because “I have control in a way that I didn’t before”. Lauren feels better physically and has a different type of body energy. She fortunately feels like someone who is pretty in control of their cognition most of the time.

title: HFC—a charitable organization founded by Lauren and Seth
content: Hilarity for Charity (HFC) is a charitable organization founded by Lauren and her husband Seth Rogen (a comedian). Part of the intent of HFC is to help others have a similarly less terrible situation. HFC is focused on Alzheimer’s disease and has two primary intentions: to help people (and their caregivers) who need help now, and to help people minimize future risk. HFC sends caregivers to people’s homes to give the primary caregiver a break. They also have a partnership with the Rosalynn Carter Institute for training these caregivers.

title: Insufficient Funding for Major Studies
content: HFC funds research, but to date they have not raised enough money to fund major studies

title: Connecting People to Understand Their Situation
content: Based on this experience, Lauren has made it a mission of HFC to help connect people to others who can understand their situation

title: COVID-19's Impact on Fundraising and Caregivers
content: COVID-19 has slowed fundraising for HFC, but as Lauren points out, while people and organizations are diverting their donations to COVID-related efforts, as they should be, we all still have brains. In addition, COVID-19 is making life for caregivers more difficult

title: Encouraging Personal Fundraising Events
content: HFC also welcomes people to have their own fundraising events on behalf of HFC. For example, one person drove a tuk-tuk across India as a fundraiser

title: Providing Hope and Control
content: "I think overall, we’re just trying to provide people the hope that I have found over the years. We started this podcast talking about my dark devastating times and that’s not who I am anymore, and that’s not my vision about all of this anymore. And I think there is so much control that can be had that we did not have even just a few years ago. And we through HFC are just trying to teach people that they have that control too." —Lauren Miller Rogen
